speakerSection.name: Gregg Vanderheiden
speakerSection.description: Dr. Vanderheiden is the Director of the Trace R&D Center and Professor in the College of Information Studies at the University of Maryland. He has been a long-time leader in the area of web accessibility, creating the first set of Web Accessibility guidelines in 1995 and serving as co-editor and co-chairing the WCAG Working Group from its inception through 2013.

speakerSection.name: Becca Blais
speakerSection.tagline: CEO and Executive Director of Bluebonnet Data
speakerSection.description: Becca Blais got her start in policy through Notre Dame (Political Science and Peace Studies) student advocacy, where she served as Student Body Vice President and later Student Body President. She is a 2017 Truman Scholar and the Co-Founder and Executive Director of Bluebonnet Data, a nonprofit that is recruiting and training the next generation of data-savvy leaders in the progressive movement.

speakerSection.name: Aedan Lombardo
speakerSection.description: Aedan Lombardo is Data Director of Bluebonnet Data, a nonprofit focused on recruiting and training the next generation of data-savvy leaders in the progressive movement. As Data Director, Aedan leads Bluebonnet's internal research initiatives and provides guidance to fellows on how to best leverage data for their campaign or cause. He graduated from Yale University in 2020 with a BA in Statistics & Data Science and prior to joining Bluebonnet as Data Director he volunteered as a Data Fellow on campaigns for municipal, state legislative, and statewide offices. He now resides in New York's Hudson Valley.

speakerSection.name: Yong Dich (Emily)
speakerSection.tagline: Board Member and Previous Technology/Infrastructure Intern at Bluebonnet Data
speakerSection.description: Yong Dich is a 2020 graduate of Harvard University, where she studied Computer Science and Folklore and Mythology. She is currently on the board of Bluebonnet Data and a software engineer with the US Census in the Economics directorate via Reveal Global. After software engineering experiences in private sector, she found her entry into civic technology through the Civic Digital Fellowship by Coding it Forward and was placed with the US Census. Her interest in the intersection of technology and social impact started through her time with undergraduate computer science & education research, Shelter Hacks, WiCS, and Tech for Social Good at Harvard as well as through external opportunities such as Impact Fellowship and Bluebonnet Data. She loves reading, podcasts, traveling, learning fun facts, tea, and corny jokes.

speakerSection.name: Cindy Cohn
speakerSection.tagline: Executive Director of the Electronic Frontier Foundation
speakerSection.description: From 2000-2015 she served as EFF’s Legal Director as well as its General Counsel where she served as lead attorney in Bernstein v. Dept. of Justice, the successful First Amendment challenge to the U.S. export restrictions on cryptography. Among other honors, Ms. Cohn was named to TheNonProfitTimes 2020 Power & Influence TOP 50 list, and in 2018, Forbes included Ms. Cohn as one of America's Top 50 Women in Tech.

speakerSection.name: David Gadsden
speakerSection.tagline: Director of Conservation Solutions at Esri
speakerSection.description: David Gadsden, Esri’s Director of Conservation Solutions, is an applied geographer with more than two decades of experience applying geospatial technology to address complex humanitarian and conservation challenges. Gadsden earned a geography degree from the University of Washington in 1995 and later served as a US Peace Corps volunteer in rural Tanzania, working on community-based natural resource management. In his early career he architected and implemented GIS solutions to address environmental, social, public safety, emergency response and construction engineering challenges while working for both commercial and nonprofit organizations. In 2002, Gadsden joined Esri, where he initially served as a technical advisor to the United Nations, US Department of State, and USAID. He has helped a diverse community leverage the “Science of Where” to address complex challenges ranging from global health, disaster response, wildlife protection, green infrastructure, tribal governance, historic preservation and community development.

speakerSection.name: Kalika Bali
speakerSection.description: Kalika Bali is a Principal Researcher at Microsoft Research India working broadly in the area of Speech and Language Technology especially in the use of linguistic models for building technology that offers a more natural Human-Computer as well as Computer-Mediated interactions, and technology for Low Resource Languages. She has been working in the field of Speech and Natural Language Processing for over two decades and believes that local language technology, especially with speech interfaces, can help millions of people gain entry into a world that is till now almost inaccessible to them.

speakerSection.name: Lili Gangas
speakerSection.description:
Lili Gangas is the Chief Technology Community Officer at the Kapor Center working to create new and more inclusive tech innovation ecosystems regionally & nationally. Her work is centered at the intersection of racial justice, technology, and action driven partnerships to tackle pressing social and economic inequities of underrepresented communities. Her areas of focus and interest include tech advocacy themes such as closing the Digital Divide, Future of Work(ers), Responsible Technology, and Ecosystem Building as they relate to new models with cross sector partners. Lili believes that it is critical that we help prepare and upskill communities of color for the future and encourage going beyond being consumers to also being creators and owners. She was a New America CA fellow focused on Tech for Good, was recognized as SF Business Times Most Influential Women in Business and SF Business Times 40 Under 40, and is an MBA lecturer at Mills College. Lili was recently a featured Salesforce Dreamforce and TEDxOakland speaker.
Before coming to the Kapor Center, Lili was an Associate Principal at Accenture Technology Lab’s Open Innovation team, based out of Silicon Valley,focused on partnerships and programming to connect startups to Fortune 500 clients. She was also a founding member of the Innovation Services team at Booz Allen specializing in crowdsourcing, prize challenges, and open data solutions at the federal level. Before that, Lili could be found in the lab working on software and hardware solutions for the aerospace industry as a Senior Multi-Disciplined Software Engineer at Raytheon Space and Airborne Systems. She is an advisor to tech focused nonprofits such as AI-4-All.org as well as community investing organizations such as The Unity Council and Pacific Community Ventures. Lili holds an MBA from New York University Stern School of Business, a B.S. in Electrical Engineering from the University of Southern California.

speakerSection.name: MJ Chun
speakerSection.tagline: Head of Product at Serve Robotics, Co-founder
speakerSection.description:
MJ Chun is Cofounder and Head of Product at Serve Robotics, a maker of sidewalk delivery robots recently spun off from Uber. MJ Chun is Cofounder and Head of Product at Serve Robotics, a maker of sidewalk delivery robots recently spun off from Uber. Serve is on a mission to shape the future of self-driving delivery and their fleet has completed tens of thousands of contactless deliveries in major U.S. cities.
MJ has spent the past 17 years developing tech products that delight users, ranging from connected devices and family robots (Anki), ecommerce marketplaces (BigCommerce), to best-selling video games and streaming services (EA).
MJ was an English Major and Public Policy Minor at Swarthmore College who originally thought she would work in health policy after graduation. It is still not clear to her parents what she does for work. She lives in San Francisco with her husband and two-year-old, and enjoys thinking about, cooking, and eating food.

speakerSection.name: Dr. Safiya Noble
speakerSection.description: Dr. Safiya U. Noble is an Associate Professor of Gender Studies and African American Studies at the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) where she serves as the Co-Founder and Director of the UCLA Center for Critical Internet Inquiry (C2i2). She holds affiliations in the School of Education & Information Studies, and is a Research Associate at the Oxford Internet Institute at the University of Oxford where she is a Commissioner on the Oxford Commission on AI & Good Governance (OxCAIGG). Dr. Noble is a board member of the Cyber Civil Rights Initiative, serving those vulnerable to online harassment. She is the author of a best-selling book on racist and sexist algorithmic bias in commercial search engines, entitled Algorithms of Oppression: How Search Engines Reinforce Racism (NYU Press), which has been widely-reviewed in scholarly and popular publications.

speakerSection.name: Sam Liang
speakerSection.description: Sam Liang is the Founder and CEO of Otter.ai, based in Silicon Valley. Otter.ai builds products to improve team collaboration, engagement, and productivity. Sam got his Ph.D in EE from Stanford University, specializing in large scale distributed Internet systems.

speakerSection.name: Chris Brust
speakerSection.description: Chris Brust is a staff machine learning engineer at Duolingo, the world's largest language-learning platform. Over the past four years, he has been a principal architect of the 'Birdbrain' ML system, which learns from half a billion exercises completed by Duolingo learners every day and is used in nearly every lesson and practice session to tailor content to the learner; he has also worked on our proprietary analytics and A/B testing systems, and has co-organized two shared tasks. He is currently a co-lead of the Learning AI Lab, a team that develops AI technology to improve the way we teach. Prior to Duolingo, Chris was a postdoc at the Perimeter Institute for Theoretical Physics and earned a Ph.D. in Physics from Johns Hopkins University.

speakerSection.name: Tyler Menezes
speakerSection.description: Tyler Menezes is the Executive Director at CodeDay, where he works to provide welcoming and diverse opportunities for under-served students to explore a future in tech and beyond. He briefly studied at University of Washington, combined with stints working in machine learning at Microsoft Research and as a programmer at several Seattle startups, led to his work finding data-driven solutions to increasing CS diversity and enrollment since 2014.

speakerSection.name: Dr. D. Sivakumar
speakerSection.description: D. Sivakumar is a computer scientist whose work has included solving deep theoretical problems in computing to building cutting-edge applications of CS and AI. His career -- as an academic, a researcher, an engineer, and in research leadership -- spans 25 years, the bulk of which was spent at IBM Almaden Research Center and Google, where he was most recently a Research Director. His recent adventure is in starting a company that aims to reimagine Search by innovative advances in natural language understanding.

speakerSection.name: Jim Fruchterman
speakerSection.description: Jim Fruchterman is a leading social entrepreneur, a MacArthur Fellow, a recipient of the Skoll Award for Social Entrepreneurship, and a Distinguished Alumnus of Caltech. His life’s work is applying technology to benefit the 95% of humanity typically neglected by for-profit tech companies.

questions.question: Is registration open?
questions.answer: Yes! Be sure to click the link at the top to register!

questions.question: Who can attend?
questions.answer: Reflections|Projections is free and open to anyone regardless of age, major, or affiliation with the University of Illinois. Come join a discussion led by some of the brightest minds in the business about the bleeding edge of the tech industry!

questions.question: Is the conference free to attend?
questions.answer: Yes! Reflections|Projections is completely free to attend! This includes MechMania and all other events.

questions.question: Will I be able to attend the conference online?
questions.answer: We will be posting zoom links on our website so you can join our events wherever you are in the world! All events will be available online or in person. For speakers that choose to attend virtually, we will be playing the talk in a conference room to be viewed.

questions.question: Will I need to show proof of vaccination in order to attend the conference in person?
questions.answer: In accordance with University guidelines, you will either need to show proof of vaccination (through your safer Illinois app or using the vaccination card granted to you) or have proof of a negative test result shown through your Safer Illinois app.

questions.question: What precautions will Reflections|Projections take regarding the COVID pandemic?
questions.answer: Reflections|Projections is committed to keeping all conference participants safe, and ensuring that we adhere to university guidelines for the event. This includes masks indoors for even fully vaccinated individuals, pre-packaged food as opposed to open containers, providing hand sanitizer, cleaning conference rooms beforehand, and other precautions that we will discuss with the department in order to make this event possible.

questions.question: How will the career fair work?
questions.answer: We will be having a virtual career fair in order to make the event more accessible and adhere to university safety guidelines. Certain companies will also have corporate days throughout the conference, with a booth and corporate representatives in person. More details regarding the platform and logistics will be communicated to attendees.

questions.question: What is MechMania?
questions.answer: MechMania is a 24-hour programming contest in which teams of students from various schools compete to create an AI capable of playing (and winning) a strategy game we have developed. The competition, from the moment it starts to the closing ceremony and awards presentation, will be livestreamed on twitch.tv. You must be registered for Reflections|Projections to compete in MechMania. You can find more info at mechmania.io.

questions.question: Who's eligible?
questions.answer: We accept teams of up to four students. All participants must actively be enrolled in a college or university, but teams do not need to be composed of students from the same school. Besides that, we accept everyone of every skill level!

questions.question: What do you need to know?
questions.answer: We accept everyone of all skill levels, but teams will have the option to program their bots in Java and Python, and run the Java engine to locally test their submissions. As such, teams should be proficient in the language they plan to use. We will provide relevant installation info on the day of the competition.

questions.question: What can you bring?
questions.answer: You can bring any reference manual(s) you want, whether it be The Art of Computer Programming or The Art of War. Absolutely no outside code is allowed. Competitors need to bring their own laptops. Due to Covid restrictions, please do not bring food into Siebel 1404 if you plan to attend in person.

questions.question: What will you do?
questions.answer: By using our provided sample starterpacks, you will implement an artificial intelligence that will play our game! The goal is simple: return a decision from a function, but the logic you take to get there is entirely up to you.

questions.question: Is registration open?
questions.answer: Yes! Please visit mechmania.io for our pre-registration form.

questions.question: What is PuzzleBang?
questions.answer: PuzzleBang is a puzzle hunt that takes place over the course of the Reflections|Projections week. Puzzles are released online at puzzlebang.com with the first puzzle coming out on Monday, September 26.  Expect one or two puzzles per day until Saturday when we release the final set of puzzles along with a metapuzzle.

questions.question: Who's eligible?
questions.answer: Anyone can play! We strongly recommend playing with friends, because the more the merrier. If you haven't met any friends who are interested in playing, sign up anyway! We'll have a discord server up this year and a  #looking-for-group channel.

questions.question: What you will need to have?
questions.answer: Access to a functional human brain, an internet connection, a computer with a current web browser, and an open mind.  We're also adding discord support this year, so a microphone + speakers will enhance the experience.

questions.question: What do you need to know?
questions.answer: Everything! No, just kidding. Wikipedia's classical cipher's page might be useful. A number of letters in the alphabet, number of cards in a deck, all the US state abbreviations, and silly other things that you've probably run across in your daily life. Some awareness of the recent memes and popular culture will probably be helpful. Knowledge of UIUC's campus layout will be really helpful.

questions.question: What do you not need to know?
questions.answer: How to write code. It might be useful to be able to write a script to print out all the ways you can rearrange a set of letters, or apply different ciphers to them, but in general, you should be able to do everything by hand or ask Google and find a tool online to do it for you.
